data.title: fundamental ProgressBar behavior improvement suggestions
data.body:
_suggested labels: enhancement, scene2d_

I think there are some aspects of the ProgressBar's behavior that need to be addressed.

![progressbar](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4956158/7299604/3a0be03c-e9d7-11e4-8078-b06694f7ed29.png)

Here's a (vertical) ProgressBar as reference to what I'm saying.
1. If the background of the ProgressBar is a NinePatchDrawable, the _knobBefore_ Drawable is not drawn over the unresizable parts of the background. I think it should be.  
   In the image, the green fill is the _knobBefore_. Both the background and _knobBefore_ are NinePatchDrawables. To my knowledge, it is not possible to draw the _knobBefore_ from the very bottom to the very top of the ProgressBar, making a filling ProgressBar impossible unless you don't use a NinePatch as background. No NinePatch would mean round edges are always stretched over the whole ProgressBar though. So in effect you have to choose between either a filling ProgressBar with no round edges or a ProgressBar with round edges but ugly _knobBefore_.  
   If the _knobBefore_ was drawn over the unresizable parts of the NinePatch background as well, this wouldn't be a problem. If the user doesn't want it to be drawn over these parts he could use a NinePatch _knobBefore_ with transparent parts, so no functionality is lost but only new added.  
   This is of course also the case regarding _knobAfter_ which should go from the _knob_ to the very end of the ProgressBar, not just to the end of the resizable/inner part of the _background_ NinePatch.
2. The green rectangle is the actual size of the ProgressBar, set with  `bar.setWidth(200); bar.setHeight(500);`. Vertical ProgressBars only adjust to their height, horizontal ProgressBars only adjust to their width. In my opinion the user should be able to size them theirselves instead of being forced to have them look 140 pixels wide/tall regardless of their actual size.

What do you think about these suggestions?

_especially adressing ProgressBar authors @badlogic and @NathanSweet_

data.title: Label setAlignment(Align.center) doesn't work properly with setEllipsis(true)
data.body:
When on a Label you set both `setAlignment(Align.center)` and `setEllipsis(true)`, the alignment is broken when the text doesn't fit.
#### Expected behaviour

When text fits:

```
    +--------+
    |  1234  |
    +--------+
```

When text doesn't fit:

```
    +--------+
    |12345...|
    +--------+
```
#### Actual behavior (libGDX 1.5.6)

When text fits:

```
    +--------+
    |  1234  |
    +--------+
```

When text doesn't fit:

```
    +--------+
 12345...    |
    +--------+
```

If you use `setAlignment(Align.right)` you get similar incorrect behavior.

data.title: build.gradle and Native libraries
data.body:
I've been trying to add a dependency on a 3rd party library that included a native .so library and I've found (as reported here https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/issues/2733) that the task 

```
tasks.withType(com.android.build.gradle.tasks.PackageApplication) { pkgTask ->
    pkgTask.jniFolders = new HashSet<File>()
   pkgTask.jniFolders.add(new File(projectDir, 'libs'))
```

was deleting it and thus was not being included in the APK.

If I'm not wrong this task was the workaround for adding native dependencies before NDK support was added to the build tools on version 0.8. From 0.8 onwards it's possible to define the jndi libs folder for a project and the plugin takes care of the rest (see http://sysmagazine.com/posts/216353/).

In our case we can keep the current directory structure (necessary for Eclipse apparently) just by setting the jndiLibs folder to 'libs' in the sourceSets element

```
 sourceSets {
        main {
            manifest.srcFile 'AndroidManifest.xml'
            java.srcDirs = ['src']
            jniLibs.srcDir 'libs'
            ...
```

Now we can comment out/delete the task and let the plugin handle it

```
//tasks.withType(com.android.build.gradle.tasks.PackageApplication) { pkgTask ->
//pkgTask.jniFolders = new HashSet<File>()
 //pkgTask.jniFolders.add(new File(projectDir, 'libs'))
```

Sorry if I'm missing a specific case here, in my tests it works nicely.

Scene2D elements (like Table and Ninepatch) only work with pixel cameras
data.body:
Like the title says, if I attempt to use a Table, Ninepatch, Label etc. in a Stage where the camera measures in world units, they will draw ridiculously large. This could be caused by the elements internally measuring everything in pixels and not converting back to world units when being drawn (i.e. I tell a Ninepatch to be 0.8x0.8 world units in size, when being drawn it knows that means 51.2x51.2 pixels if each world unit is 64x64 pixels, and then draws at that size instead of the 0.8x0.8), but it could be something else entirely. Besides having a separate stage for these elements I do not know any ways to fix this without going into the libraries code.

Is a fix for this feasible or will I have to live with the workaround?

3D ParticleSystem crashes second time the game starts on Android
data.body:
Hey,

I'm using 3d Particle Effect in my Game on Android. However, the game will crash the second time I start it. Here is the error log:

```
04-07 15:32:10.680: E/AndroidRuntime(31308): FATAL EXCEPTION: GLThread 644
04-07 15:32:10.680: E/AndroidRuntime(31308): com.badlogic.gdx.utils.GdxRuntimeException: java.lang.NullPointerException
04-07 15:32:10.680: E/AndroidRuntime(31308):    at com.badlogic.gdx.assets.AssetManager.handleTaskError(AssetManager.java:540)
04-07 15:32:10.680: E/AndroidRuntime(31308):    at com.badlogic.gdx.assets.AssetManager.update(AssetManager.java:356)
04-07 15:32:10.680: E/AndroidRuntime(31308):    at lu.internet.alain_krier.ggame.World.update(World.java:239)
04-07 15:32:10.680: E/AndroidRuntime(31308):    at lu.internet.alain_krier.ggame.screens.GameScreen.update(GameScreen.java:30)
04-07 15:32:10.680: E/AndroidRuntime(31308):    at lu.internet.alain_krier.ggame.screens.GameScreen.render(GameScreen.java:35)
04-07 15:32:10.680: E/AndroidRuntime(31308):    at com.badlogic.gdx.Game.render(Game.java:46)
04-07 15:32:10.680: E/AndroidRuntime(31308):    at lu.internet.alain_krier.ggame.Ggame.render(Ggame.java:46)
04-07 15:32:10.680: E/AndroidRuntime(31308):    at com.badlogic.gdx.backends.android.AndroidGraphics.onDrawFrame(AndroidGraphics.java:422)
04-07 15:32:10.680: E/AndroidRuntime(31308):    at android.opengl.GLSurfaceView$GLThread.guardedRun(GLSurfaceView.java:1516)
04-07 15:32:10.680: E/AndroidRuntime(31308):    at android.opengl.GLSurfaceView$GLThread.run(GLSurfaceView.java:1240)
04-07 15:32:10.680: E/AndroidRuntime(31308): Caused by: java.lang.NullPointerException
04-07 15:32:10.680: E/AndroidRuntime(31308):    at com.badlogic.gdx.assets.AssetManager.get(AssetManager.java:148)
04-07 15:32:10.680: E/AndroidRuntime(31308):    at com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g3d.particles.batches.BillboardParticleBatch.load(BillboardParticleBatch.java:678)
04-07 15:32:10.680: E/AndroidRuntime(31308):    at com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g3d.particles.ParticleEffectLoader.loadSync(ParticleEffectLoader.java:117)
04-07 15:32:10.680: E/AndroidRuntime(31308):    at com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g3d.particles.ParticleEffectLoader.loadSync(ParticleEffectLoader.java:29)
04-07 15:32:10.680: E/AndroidRuntime(31308):    at com.badlogic.gdx.assets.AssetLoadingTask.handleAsyncLoader(AssetLoadingTask.java:139)
04-07 15:32:10.680: E/AndroidRuntime(31308):    at com.badlogic.gdx.assets.AssetLoadingTask.update(AssetLoadingTask.java:89)
04-07 15:32:10.680: E/AndroidRuntime(31308):    at com.badlogic.gdx.assets.AssetManager.updateTask(AssetManager.java:477)
04-07 15:32:10.680: E/AndroidRuntime(31308):    at com.badlogic.gdx.assets.AssetManager.update(AssetManager.java:354)
04-07 15:32:10.680: E/AndroidRuntime(31308):    ... 8 more
```

I figured out, that it is because ParticleSystem class uses the Singleton Pattern and therefore has a static variable holding the instance(which causes trouble due to the Android Life Cycle). I called the constructor of ParticleSystem manually and then it works.

I suggest removing the Singleton pattern and force the user to manually instantiate the ParticleSystem class to be able to use it.

regards,
Alain
